info.game_comments:
2003 College Championship quarterfinal game 1.
From Yale University.

(1, 1).clue: Alphabetically, it's the first mammal that could be in a "Starts With 2 Vowels" category

(2, 1).clue: Rich guy Ralph Fiennes falls in love with hotel employee Jennifer Lopez in this Cinderella story

(3, 1).clue: The name of this large land creature is from the Greek for "nose-horned"

(4, 1).clue: The tale of the tortoise & the hare comes to life in Karen Corey-Malik's ballet based on this man's fables

(5, 1).clue: The first 2 ingredients listed in Cheez Whiz are whey & this (it does a body good)

(6, 1).clue: To save someone costs when replying to your letter, enclose an SASE, which stands for this

(1, 2).clue: It's the main metal in both bronze & brass

(2, 2).clue: When asked what she got on this standardized college placement exam, Jen quipped, "Nail polish"

(3, 2).clue: This 6-letter word for the spout at the end of a hose is a diminutive form of "nose"

(4, 2).clue: "Something" tells us the ABT presented a ballet tribute to this former Beatle who passed away in 2001

(5, 2).clue: This company's Wheat Thins are thin, baked wheat crackers; its Triscuit thin crisps, thin, baked wheat wafers

(6, 2).clue: In chat room abbreviations, WYSIWYG is "what you see is what you get"; YGWYPF is this
(6, 2).correct response: you get what you pay for

(1, 3).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew at Cape Cod, Massachusetts)  When lightning strikes the sand, it can melt & fuse it into a type of this, called fulgurite

(2, 3).clue: Ben Affleck plays a lowly thug who falls for female gangster J. Lo. in this 2003 romantic comedy

(3, 3).clue: Henry I of England fixed this unit of measure as the distance from his nose to the thumb of his outstretched arm

(4, 3).clue: Czar Nicholas II & this empress appear in "Anastasia", a ballet about one of their daughters

(5, 3).clue: In 1932 Elmer Doolin paid a guy in Texas $100 for his corn chip recipe & founded this brand

(6, 3).clue: Computer users should know that BBS stands for this

(1, 4).clue: From their size, about 2.5 cm. & how they crawl, caterpillars of the moth family Geometridae are often called this

(2, 4).clue: When Jen wore that now-infamous green Versace dress to the 2000 Grammys, he was her date

(3, 4).clue: Edmond Rostand won international fame with this 1897 play about a long-nosed, star-crossed poet

(4, 4).clue: Arrgh!  A pirate is the hero of "Le Corsaire", based on an 1814 poem by this British lord

(5, 4).clue: As you can see, the logo on this product's can has had some work done over the years

(6, 4).clue: EOE in a job listing in the newspaper classifieds stands for this

(1, 5).clue: This property is the reason a rubber ball bounces & a stretched rubber band springs back to size

(2, 5).clue: The video for this song pays homage to the movie "Flashdance", with Jen as the welder/dancer

(3, 5).clue: This Indian tribe's name comes from the French for "pierced noses", ironically a practice they rarely engaged in

(4, 5).clue: In 2003 the dance theatre of this N.Y. neighborhood presented the world premiere of "St. Louis Woman: A Blues Ballet"

(5, 5).clue: What would you do for this ice cream treat introduced by the Isaly family in 1922

(6, 5).clue: The abbreviation for pound, lb., stands for this Latin word that means pound

(1, 1).clue: In the history of jazz, Dizzy Gillespie & Louis Armstrong were 2 of the greatest players of this instrument

(2, 1).clue: Inventor of the telephone who's a nice salad ingredient

(3, 1).clue: She makes her first entrance with "Her ladies, the train, with eunuchs fanning her"

(4, 1).clue: A second grade science experiment includes labeling magnets with these 2 math symbols

(5, 1).clue: Lizard Point, from the Cornish for "court on a height", is this island's southernmost point

(6, 1).clue: From 1980 to 1998 this rose worldwide from 61 to 67

(1, 2).clue: Once called "The Capstone of Negro Education", this Washington, D.C. university opened its doors in 1867

(2, 2).clue: This new Dynamic Duo is made up of Bruce Wayne's superhero self & a famous bandit of Sherwood Forest

(3, 2).clue: Title adjective Shakespeare used to describe Mistresses Ford & Page

(4, 2).clue: Sixth grade social studies teach about renewable energy, like solar, & nonrenewable, like this solid fossil fuel

(5, 2).clue: At Pittsburgh's "The Point", the Allegheny & Monongahela meet to form this third river

(6, 2).clue: Of 2, 4, 8 or 16, the number of hours a day the TV's on in the average American home

(1, 3).clue: While an editor for Random House books, she wrote her first novel, "The Bluest Eye"

(2, 3).clue: Macedonian world conqueror who became a tragic F. Scott Fitzgerald hero

(3, 3).clue: This daughter of Prospero was but a few years old when they were exiled

(4, 3).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew at a chalkboard)  Eighth graders should be able to deal with this type of equation [y = 3x + 7 is shown as the example] that uses variables without exponents

(5, 3).clue: A high point of your trip to Santiago might be seeing this hemispheric high point nearby

(6, 3).clue: According to Conde Nast, in the U.S. the average cost of this event is now $22,360

(1, 4).clue: Currently, they're the 2 highest-ranking African-Americans in President Bush's administration

(2, 4).clue: "Colorful" 14th century plague that became a hit play by Arthur Miller
(2, 4).correct response: The Black Death of a Salesman

(3, 4).clue: Figure it out: she has the third line in "Macbeth"

(4, 4).clue: Ninth graders know that electrically neutral atoms have the same number of these 2 particles

(5, 4).clue: Cape Andreas is at the pointy end of this island in the eastern Mediterranean

(6, 4).clue: In March 2003 astronomers said this grayish light brown was the average color of the universe

(1, 5).clue: In 2003 the Postal Service did him justice by honoring him with the stamp seen here

(2, 5).clue: Snoopy's owner who's one of the most poisonous types of spiders in the U.S.

(3, 5).clue: Briseis in Homer's "Iliad" evolved in tales over time to wind up as this Shakespeare title character

(4, 5).clue: Tenth grade?  Time for this 1840s French novel about a man falsely imprisoned who wants revenge

(5, 5).clue: The instantaneous North Pole is the point where this imaginary line would poke out

(6, 5).clue: A Frenchman eats 53 pounds of this a year; an American, 31; a Japanese, 4

(0, 0).clue: At the end of the American Revolution, this country controlled New Orleans
